characters: CAMERA ROLLS IN SLOWLY FOR TIGHT TWO OF THE ADMIRAL
UP INTO FACES OF REEF AND WENDOVER
SCREEN WHIRLS OPTICALLY INTO A SPIRAL BLUR
TOWARD WOUND MADE BY TIGER SH
CAMERA MOVES IN FOR BIG HEAD OF WENDOVER
KENT, REEF, WENDOVER AND SIR IAN
THROUGH IRIS DOWN RAMP TO FLOOR
UP PAST 'EYE' AT REEF IN IRIS
OVER SHOULDERS OF REEF AND JULIE

dialogues.speaker: NORTH POLE AREA
dialogues.text: With, possibly, radically-designed jet planes flying over the Arctic wastes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It cost Commander Robert Peary twenty years or unremitting hard- ship and misery to reach the North Pole, finally, in 1909.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would have astounded Peary to learn that, by the late 1950's and early 60's, the vast, frozen top-of-the-world he pioneered had become a vital highway for world travel and commerce.  Not just in the skies...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...but also deep under the ice, in the frigid, five-million-square- mile depths of the Arctic Ocean.

dialogues.speaker: CARGO SUB STURGEON
dialogues.text: The huge, heavy vessel glides smoothly along, between underwater mountains, following the well-beaten Polar route.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here great passenger and cargo- carrying atomic submarines glided by the dozens, back and forth across the Pole, until a series of mysterious undersea disasters threatened to close the Arctic route forever.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE SHOT
dialogues.text: As it glides, very close, PAST CAMERA, so we can read the name:  U.S.A.S. STURGEON (United States Atom Sub Sturgeon) on the bow.  We may spot the closed-circuit TV camera on the surface of the conning tower.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The decisive moment came May 3, at 1315 hours, when the undersea atomic liner, Sturgeon, largest of them all, reached 87 degrees, 10 minutes north latitude - only a few miles from the North Pole it- self!

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWATER ICE CAVE
dialogues.text: In the depths of it appears a distant, faint ball of glowing light.  The ball begins moving toward CAMERA, slowly, becoming larger and larger.  There may be a FAINT, WEIRD ELECTRICAL HUM just audible from it.

dialogues.speaker: CARGO SUB STURGEON
dialogues.text: It moves ahead, unconscious of impending doom, the Peep- Peep of its sonar impulses now gradually increasing in pitch, Doppler effect, as they echo back from the approaching blob of light.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAUCER
dialogues.text: Dimly seen, a vague, indistinct shape (thru this sequence -- it approaches -- a huge, oval-shaped disc, with what seems to be a revolving turret, or lighthouse, on top. The Peep-Peep of the Sturgeon sonar has now risen to a frantic scream, and the MAGNETIC, LOW-FREQUENCY HUM from the saucer becomes louder and louder

dialogues.speaker: PAN SHOT WITH STURGEON
dialogues.text: The great atom sub glides past camera, but now, as we are shooting from her stern over the bow, we see the screws halt, then go into reverse, and she begins to back away, back TOWARD CAMERA.  Then, in the b.g., we see the saucer, the great, eerie 'eye' or whatever it is, looming like a searchlight on her top, and the oval shape seeming like a great mass of glowing energy. The saucer is easily overtaking the reversed Sturgeon, when:

dialogues.speaker: THE SAUCER
dialogues.text: It moves to a position nearly filling screen, when... A great bolt of sheer high-frequency energy - like an undersea lightning bolt - stabs out from somewhere in the saucer, and lances out TOWARD CAMERA.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAUCER AND STURGEON
dialogues.text: The great, stabbing bolt of energy impinges on the hull of the Sturgeon, and for an instant, the entire sub seems to glow with radiant light.  Then, in closer de- tails, we see the effects...

dialogues.speaker: BOW OF STURGEON
dialogues.text: It seems to melt away (or collapse) like a shell of paraffin over a fire.  The water boils and hisses about it.

dialogues.speaker: CONNING TOWER
dialogues.text: The radio antenna, the periscope, the mast, the tower itself - all seem to melt, and collapse.

dialogues.speaker: THE STURGEON
dialogues.text: What is left of the Sturgeon, glowing and hissing, still red hot, begins rising to the surface, towards the ice-layer.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAUCER
dialogues.text: It reverses, draws back into the ice-cave from which it issued.

dialogues.speaker: ABOVE ICE
dialogues.text: And now, she seems to be rising in a tremendous crunch- ing, grinding, writhing activity.  Finally, it breaks completely, and for a moment, the red-hot hull of the Sturgeon is visible in the cracking, grinding masses of ice.  Then, a larger hiss of steam, and finally a ROAR of earthquake volume, a fireball, then a mushroom cloud.  The atomic reactor of the Sturgeon has blown up, the ship is vaporized to nothingness.  As the atomic cloud rises up toward camera...

dialogues.speaker: SCREEN WHIRLS OPTICALLY INTO A SPIRAL BLUR
dialogues.text: and then

dialogues.speaker: CLCSEUP
dialogues.text: This comes WHIRLING INTO VIEW, then WHIRLING STOPS and we can read the headline in the CAPITAL TIMES. CLOSE ARCTIC SEA LANE AFTER EPIC DISASTER!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mysterious Loss of Sturgeon, Latest in Series of Polar Tragedies, Prompts Drastic Action.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prererably of the Pentagon.  A helicopter shot of it would be most readily identifiable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: According to the official reports, the next phase of the life-and- death drama occurred May 10, in Washington --

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP PANELED DOOR
dialogues.text: On which is lettered:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) BUREAU OF ARCTIC DEFENSE

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- at a hush-hush, super-secret meeting in the Arctic theater war room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This room is, more than anything else, a system of maps and charts - a huge detail of the Arctic ocean occupy- ing an entire wall behind the conference table.  On it are small, magnetic models of submarines, defense stations, etc.  Also, to one side, is a huge globe of the world, on a revolving stand.  File cabinets, rolled maps and charts, shelves of references, navigation guides, etc.  All business; no time wasted on decora- tion.  There is an electric lock on the door; no one can 'burst in' on the excuse of making a mistake.

dialogues.speaker: ADMIRAL TERHUNE
dialogues.text: The burly, grim-faced Admiral, in uniform, is at the head of the conference table.  There is an intercom on a small stand beside his position at the table.  The Admiral has a sheaf of reports and photographs, also a stack of mimeographed 'briefs' at his elbow.  No nonsense; Terhune speaks in clipped, brief phrases, almost as if he has digested sentences down to short, terse bursts before 'releasing' them from his lips. The Admiralts lips are moving as we first see him, but we do not hear his speech until the Narrator is finished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral Terhune, in charge of the Arctic Theater for the Joint Chiefs, well knew the effect the 'leak' of any of the explosive information would have on the world civilian population.  So the Admiral was determined:  There would be no leaks!

dialogues.speaker: PAST CONFERENCE TABLE
dialogues.text: And now we see Admiral Terhune in the close f.g., and the other participants of the meeting - DR. CLIFFORD KENT a practical, 'egghead' scientist, Chief of Scientific Research and Weapons Development; SIR IAN HUNT, English, winner of the Nobel prize for Oceanography, and Defense Secretary Murdock, distinguished, white-haired. There is a KNOCK.  Admiral Terhune presses the button, the lock BUZZES, and the door opens. COMMANDER WENDOVER steps inside.  He is a hard-bitten, intelligent young-old man of about forty.  Years of responsibility have made him older mentally than physical He is the highest type of the professional navy man, the elite of the new craft, the atomic submarine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Admiral Terhune!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He manages a smile, puts out his hand as he crosses to the Admiral's place at the table, in a TIGHT GROUP SHOT with the other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (addressing the men at the table) Gentlemen, this is the man we've been waiting for - Skipper of the atom killer sub, Tiger Shark - Commander Dan Wendover. (indicating) This is Justin Murdock, Secretary of Defense...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Murdock...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I know you've heard of Dr. Clifford Kent, Dan --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendover puts out his hand and the scientist takes it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Commander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Kent had a lot to do with the development and design of your boat. (continued)

dialogues.speaker: REVISED 5-26-59 "ATOMIC SUBMARINE" 7.
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (indicating) Sir Ian Hunt just flew in from London.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impressed) Are you the Doctor Hunt - Nobel prize winner for Oceanography?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling) Let's say I took the bows for a team of brrlliant associates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They take their seats at the table.  Terhune indicates a place for Wendover; meanwhile, he pulls a sheet of paper from a file folder in front of him.  Looking at them all in turn to command attention, the Admiral says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, to begin, let me read you just one line from a detailed staff study prepared for the Joint Chiefs: "In our judgment, these Arctic disasters may prove the gravest emergency in all history."

dialogues.speaker: PANNING OVER FACES
dialogues.text: As part of the above line carries over scene.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any comments on that statement?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir Ian, in typical English underplay fashion, comments:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bit on the fanciful side, isn't it, Sir?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Admiral smiles wryly, murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Possibly, possibly. (then, a new thought, taking another paper from the folder) Let me read you a partial list of observed phenomena: 1.  Complete disruption of communica- tions with Dew line warning stations. 2.  Destruction of four surface vessels, largest, 10,000 tons. 3.  Radioactivity in Arctic waters, floe ice and bergs. 4.  Peculiar television images preceding each distress call. 5.  Seven Polar atom subs, vanished without a trace! (a grim smile) "Fanciful" did you say, Sir Ian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To INTERCUT above, while Admiral reads.

dialogues.speaker: TIGHT GROUP
dialogues.text: The Admiral looks up expectantly into the faces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we come to you, Dan.  You skipper the Tiger Shark, the most advanced, the deadliest killer sub in the fleet.  Right now she's undergoing emergency, around the clock modification in the Bremerton navy yard. The Admiral pulls a cross-section of the Tiger Shark from his pile of documents, uses a pencil to indicate his point as he says: ADMIRAL (cont'd) The orders call for special obser- vation and testing instruments here...

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: As the Admiral's pencil, as a pointer, follows his words, he explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Removal of all but two atomic torpedos.  Special launching equipment for water-to-air ballistic missiles.  A special escape hatch in the keel for the Lungfish.

dialogues.speaker: FAVORING WENDOVER AND ADMIRAL
dialogues.text: As Wendover frowns, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Lungfish?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A special deep-exploration device - sort of an animated diving bell. Captain Siguard Nielsen developed it, after he retired, if you remem- ber? (tossing the diagram back on the pile) He'll be going with you - (then, indicating the other two scientists) - along with Dr. Kent, and Sir Ian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendover's face becoming more and more grim as the Admiral explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Special orders are being cut recalling your entire crew from leave, effective at once. There's a fast jet at National Airport waiting to fly you, Dr. Kent and Sir Ian to Seattle.

dialogues.speaker: CAMERA MOVES IN FOR BIG HEAD OF WENDOVER
dialogues.text: as the Admiral concludes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Mission of the Tiger Shark is to hunt down and identify the cause of these Arctic disasters.  If humanly possible, you will remove it:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A modern bachelor apartment - living room and bedroom combination, nicely furnished, with a kitchenette behind a pass-through bar at the other end of the room. This doubles as a bar for mixing drinks.  Empty glasses and the remnants of snacks are scattered about.

dialogues.speaker: 33-C APARTMENT DOOR
dialogues.text: LIEUTENANT DAVE MILBURN, ex-Naval Academy halfback and inter-collegiate boxing champion, hard-nosed and trigger-tempered, is reluctantly taking leave from Reef's party.  His pretty, placid wife, HELEN, is indeavoring to get him through the open door and cut his 'farewell scene' short.  Dave is slightly, but not objectionably, high.  REEF HOLLOWAY, a handsome, capable, relaxed Annapolis-type, is smiling amiably and bantering with Dave, all the while trying to usher him out with determined speed.  But it is not easy to get Dave through the door.  He is chattering constantly, in a lecturing tone, to someone inside the apartment o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly) ...Not that I don't think our Lieutenant Commander Holloway is the finest exec in the sub fleet, Julie...and not that he isn't the best friend I have -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pulling Dave by his arm) Come on, Dave.  You talk too much.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Quiet, Little Mother! (back to Julie o.s.) I feel it behooves me to warn you -

dialogues.speaker: JULIE
dialogues.text: perched on the arm of an overstuffed chair, in all her lush female magnificence - contoured and accoutered elegantly - with fine legs, long and sexy. Julie is drool-bait, especially for an undersea sailor who only comes up for air and 'so forth' every three months.  Julie smiles to herself as she listens to Dave's slightly thick, but earnest advice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing, o.s.) Our friend Reef is no less than Number One Howl of the entire sub Wolf Pack.  Nuclear powered!  When it comes to women, he has a built-in sonar detector that -

dialogues.speaker: REEF DAVE HELEN
dialogues.text: Reef is trying to crowd Dave through the door from behind while Helen is tugging away at him from the outer portion of the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, Dave Old Buddy, you know you're exaggerating - (to Helen) What do you think of this husband of yours?  On most boats a certain loyalty exists between the Exec and his Navigation and Firing Officer. (he sighs tragically) But unfortunately, in the case of Lieutenant Dave Milburn of the Tiger Shark and myself -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fighting his way back inside, militantly) But Julie's a nice girl, and I've seen you work.  She deserves a fighting chance!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Helen.  I appeal to you -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clutching Dave by both shoulders and staring him in the eye) Dave!  Look at me!  I am the mother of your three children!  Now please take me home to them.  At once! Dave smiles weakly, now feeling the drinks, bows heroically to the room at large, and exits scene under Helen's guiding arm.  Reef closes the door behind them with an elaborate sigh, then CAMERA PANS WITH HIM into scene with Julie.  She looks up at him impishly and smiles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave is exaggerating.  Just think, a man spends three months in a deep freeze. It'd take his whole shore leave just to thaw him out.  By that time, he's ready to report back!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It won't take me long to defrost - not around you! The moment is pregnant with anticipation as Reef meets the unspoken challenge in Julie's eyes as we

dialogues.speaker: BIG HEADS
dialogues.text: In a deep, torried kiss on the couch.  Eyes closed, they enthusiastically plumb the depths of feeling, then, at last, reluctantly, they break apart.  Julie sighs deeply.  Reef shakes his head, like a boxer who has sustained a knockout punch, trying to clear it.  CAMERA PULLS BACK for MED. TWO.  Julie, unable to speak for a moment, throws a quick look at Reef, who seems to be gulping for air, then she reaches for a cigarette from a box on the coffee table.  She drops two or three as she fumbles for one and finally gets it in her mouth. Reef picks up a table lighter, strikes it, holds it to her cigarette.  But his arm is trembling so he cannot hold it steady.  Finally, Julie grasps his wrist, holds the flame steady, then contrives to bring the tip of the cigarette in contact with it.  She leans back, takes a deep drag, only now dares to speak.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (ruefully) What was I saying...about thawing out icebergs? Reef manages a tiny smile.  Then he observes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You never can tell about ice- bergs.  Only one-ninth above water. Julie weighs this, then studies Reef appraisingly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After that kiss - I'd say that's about right. Reef snuggles closer to her, slips an arm about her waist, murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you feel anything?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous, dis- traught) Are you kidding??? She takes a couple of rapid puffs, reaches for her drink, takes a long pull at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean - that this is the be- ginning of something - that it wasn't just...accidental, our getting together?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) Original! (staring off, as if to recall) Isn't the next chorus something about:  'Let's not waste one precious golden moment - any second, there could be a knock on the door, and - Reef covers her mouth with his fingertips, murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stranger things have happened, you know.  I've had leaves can- celled like - He snaps his fingers.  Now Julie covers his lips, murmurs with unmistakable import:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then by all means, let's not waste time! And she kisses him - hard, enthusiastically.  Immedi- ately, happ1ly, Reef enters into the spirit of the thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (OMITTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A uniform glove.  It comes up to the bell, which is be- neath a card reading:  LT. COMM. RICH. L. HOLLOWAY, U.S.N The gloved finger punches the bell.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still kissing.  Julie murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear a bell. Eyes closed, Reef murmurs:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hear a whole carillon of 'em! And he kisses her again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it leaves the bell, begins BANGING on the door in- sistently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Again, frowning, she listens:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that pounding? Reef, eyes still closed, takes her hand, places it over his heart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmurs) Need I say more? And he kisses her again.  The POUNDING STOPS.

dialogues.speaker: OVER SHOULDERS OF REEF AND JULIE
dialogues.text: And now Julie, looking over Reef's shoulder, sees an envelope pushed under the door from the hall outside. She reacts, taps him on the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistently) Reef - look!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reluctantly, he turns, sees the envelope.  He frowns at her.  With extreme reluctance, he goes to the door, stoops down, picks up the envelope, removes the contents. Julie waits anxiously. Suddenly, Reef grasps the significance, slaps his fore- head in exasperation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) What's wrong?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She jumps up, goes over to him, grasps his wrist, looks at the papers.  She, too, reacts, as Reef tragically slap his forehead again, looks regretfully at her - this lovel willing morsel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And he is almost crying as we -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No Admittance Except to Authorized U.S. Navy Personnel CAMERA PANS OFF SIGN to pick up jeep which pulls up to the front of the gate leading to the pier.  Reef Holloway very grim-faced, very disgusted, climbs out, takes his sea bag from the vehicle.  The jeep pulls away.  Reef, shaking his head regretfully, starts toward the Marine guard at the door.

dialogues.speaker: 40A NAVY YARD
dialogues.text: CHIEF OF THE BOAT 'GRIFF' GRIFFIN, an 'old Navy' man with clipboard, is checking off seamen, one by one, as they pass through the gate, murmuring their names and passing on the submarine o.s. As Reef approaches, LIEUT. DAVE MILBURN intercepts him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reef!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glumly) So they caught up with you, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sadly) At the worst possible moment. Tomorrow is Janie's birthday. Poor little kid has looked forward for two months to having her Daddy home.  Now -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unimpressed) That's the worst possible moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowning) What could be worse than disappoint- ing a little girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (flatly) Disappointing a big girl!

dialogues.speaker: 40B, (CONTINUED)
dialogues.text: Dave, with a wicked grin, takes this big.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie! (he laughs cruelly, unsympathetically) Reef throws him a dirty, betrayed look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they start through the gate past Griff, who acknowledg them.  Dave laughs heartily, claps Reef sympathetically o the shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tough, old buddy!  Really tough!

dialogues.speaker: WENDOVER HUNT KEN
dialogues.text: As Dave and Reef come down ladder and greet Wendover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Thought you were going to Washington, Skipper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did go.  Just back. (then) Reef, these are a couple of our passengers - Sir Ian Hunt, and Dr. Clifford Kent.  My exec, Commander Richard Holloway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking hands) I met Dr. Kent, once.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice to see you again, Commander.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Are you men going with us?  What for?  Where -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (non-commitally) We'll discuss that later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tell Chief Griffin to report to me as soon as the crew is aboard. The seaman acknowledges the order and exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Kent and Sir Ian) My yeoman will show you to your quarters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you. One of the seamen leads the way out bulkhead door to the wardroom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 42A    EXT. NAVY YARD - AT GATE (as in 40-A) The seaman who reported Wendover's message is just exiting scene.  Griffin is checking names off on his roster as YEOMAN CHESTER TUTTLE, rumor-monger of the Tiger Shark, approaches the Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the scoop, Griff?  Hauled out in the middle of the night - all leaves cancelled.  We goin' to war, or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (logically) Don't you worry, Chester.  When the Skipper wants you to know what's going on, he'll tell you.  Okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not satisfied) I don't like it.  This is all mighty funny -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (non-commitally) Isn't it, though? (then, motioning with his pencil) Suppose you get aboard, anyway, huh? Disgruntled, Chester passes through the gate, as Griff checks him off on the roster and grins after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is the 'brain' of the sub - the controls, the TV monitors, the sonar sets, the 'Christmas Tree' panel of warning lights, etc.

dialogues.speaker: THE CON
dialogues.text: Dave Milburn is already busy checking the equipment. The other seamen are preparing the boat for sea.  Reef turns to Wendover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I'll stow my gear. But Wendover, with a peculiar look, frowns, and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm - afraid I have some bad news for you, Reef - (as Reef looks at him) You'll have to share quarters, this trip.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns, puzzled) Who with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Neilsen.  He'll be - -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grins) 'Doctor' Neilsen?  When did that happen?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cheerfully) It'll be all right.  We're old friends! Now Reef is down below deck level.  Wendover turns towards Dave.  Wendover shrugs helplessly.  Dave re- turns it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking the plot board) Get ready.  We shove off as soon as Griff reports all the crew aboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, Skipper. He goes to work, as Wendover smiles peculiarly at the bulkhead door through which Reef just passed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he climbs down a ladder into FRAME, then PAN WITH HIM as he eases past a couple of seamen and arrives at the entrance to the exec compartment.  He frowns as he sees a sign by entrance.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: It is only stuck on by scotch tape, below the normal exec sign.  It reads:  DR. NEILSEN.

dialogues.speaker: REEF
dialogues.text: He hesitates only a second, knocks, then pushes drapes aside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters, smiling cheerfully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand we'll be sharing quarters, Skipper - (but then, his grin fades, becomes a look of disgust, loathing) Carl!  You - !

dialogues.speaker: REEF AND CARL NEILSEN
dialogues.text: CARL NEILSEN has the look of an ascetic - thin, sensi- tive features, a nervous, intense manner - the 'egg- head' appearance.  He turns, reacts to Reef's presence. He is smoking a cigarette in rapid, nervous puffs. Reef sinks, disgusted onto the bunk.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should have suspectcd, when I heard that 'Doctor.'  I thought it was your father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was supposed to be.  Dad had a heart attack, two days ago.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (alarmed) How is he - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was moderate.  He'll be all right. (then) But it was out of the question, his coming along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgusted) And they thought you could re- place the Skipper? Carl displays a trace of anger for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was no choice.  Dad and I developed the Lungfish together. Except for him, I'm the only one qualified to dive in it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could train someone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not in two days. (then, earnestly) Look:  Do you think I wanted to come?  If it didn't mean so much to Dad - proving his depth-explorer - it's the last thing I'd want! Reef's lip curls contemptuously.  He mutters slowly, angrily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That I can believe! Carl drops his eyes at the intensity of Reef's stare. He turns to his gear, begins unpacking his essentials. Reef shakes his head vaguely, worriedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 50 thru  (OMITTED) 53

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It makes a turn in the channel, then heads up the Sound, past Seattle, toward the open sea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Tiger Shark left her dock at Bremerton at 0335 hours, the morning of May 11, on what was to prove the strangest, most fearful voyage ever made by a submarine, atomic or otherwise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He carefully opens a compartment of his desk, locked by a combination lock, takes out the log book and the sealed orders for the voyage.  Then, replacing the orders in the compartment, he takes a pen and begins making an entry in the log.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Simultaneously with the 'Shark's' departure, and with his crew still in the dark concerning their secret, fateful mission, Skipper Wendover made the first notation in the log...

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: As Wendover's hand writes, carefully and precisely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CREW - SPECIAL PASSENGERS KENT, HUNT, NEILSEN.  WILL BRIEF CREW IN TWO HOURS AFTER CLEARING SOUND...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...The men would remain un-briefed for two hours, until the Tiger Shark cleared Puget Sound and was headed for the open sea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which has a series of long tables and benches, re- movable when the room is to be used for other pur- poses.  To one side is the pass-through to the galley,

dialogues.speaker: REVISED 5-26-59 "ATOMIC SUBMARINE" 20.
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) where there is always a cook on duty to feed and coffee men coming off watch.  There are several crew members drinking coffee at the tables now.  We see CPO Griff Griffin enter, almost stumble and fall over a huge pile of equipment on the floor - aqualungs, face masks, tanks, fins, rubber suits, etc. - sharkman outfits. Griff explodes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who the devil belongs to this... gear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We do, Chief. And AL POWELL, a long, lean drink-of-water, and his partner, DON CARNEY, shorter, stockier, an ill-assorted pair, step into scene, looking somewhat uneasily at the irate Chief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh?  You two guys - what do you do around here?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Underwater demolition.  Seamen First Class Powell... (indicating the taller) ...and I'm Carney.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exasperated) Yeah, I know - so you're frogmen!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're off tin cans.  We've looked this pig-boat over from fore-to-aft, but can't seem to find an empty locker to stow our stuff.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: An empty locker in a sub?  Are you kidding? (then, hands on hips) This whole deal is making less and less sense to me.  What're frogmen doing aboard the Tiger Shark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Following orders, like everybody else in the navy. (he takes out his and Powell's, hands them to Griff) Griff examines them, scratches the back of his neck, shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beats me. (then, handing back the orders) I don't envy you swabbies, swimmin' in that North Pole ice water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Meantime, where'll we stash these gizmos? Griff gestures for them to pick it up, and follow him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on.  Maybe we can hide it somewhere in the aft torpedo room. Powell and Carney pick up their gear, follow Griff aft.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The only portion of the sub above water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shortly before dawn, the Tiger Shark, running submerged at better than thirty knots, had left the Sound behind and was headed for the open sea.

dialogues.speaker: WENDOVER
dialogues.text: as he climbs down a ladder from an upper hatch into the passage to the ward room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ward room, officers' dining room and "social" area, where the ship's officers, including Reef and Dave, the scientists, Carl Neilsen and Griff, are assembled.  Griff has a microphone ready for the Captain, as he enters. Wendover sits down, as Griff steps back a pace or two. Wendover takes out his sealed orders, opens them, glances through them, then hands them to Reef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These are our orders, Reef.  Better look them over while I fill in the crew. Reef takes them, and is reading them intently while the Captain is saying into the microphone:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now hear this: All men of the Tiger Shark.  This is the Captain speaking. (he takes a deep breath) I know you're wondering about all the mystery -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In thc (a) torpedo room (b) crew dining room (c) control room, as desired, to intercut Wendover's briefing.  All the faces are sober, xxx tense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filter) Our mission is so dangerous it had to be kept completely secret. It's our job to find out what caused the disasters under the Arctic ice.  Once we cross the Arctic Circle, any command you hear will be the real thing, remember that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he finishes, his face set, solemn, sober.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's about it.  Now you know as much as I do - as much as anybody does - (a faint, grim smile) I assured Washington this was the best crew of the best sub in the fleet.  I know you won't make a liar out of me! Wendover clicks off the mike, hands it to Griff, who solemnly hangs it up.  Dave heaves a deep sigh, relieving tension, breathes a solemn:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well! Reef, grim, his face frozen, hands the orders back to Wendover.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (slowly, considering) I think I should have joined the Air Force! And the members of the group manage a faint smile.

dialogues.speaker: CARL
dialogues.text: Nervously he studies Reef.  He is visible just beyond, looks up, meets the glance.  Carl turns ostentatiously away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And the notation:  MAY 18, 1200 HOURS, STILL RUNNING

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And over the moving hand we:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With a moving course line of the Tiger Shark's voyage from Puget Sound north into Arctic waters.  At this point she is possibly about opposite Juneau, but far out in the Pacific. Over above two scenes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A week later, the Tiger Shark was still running due north at cruising speed.  So far the voyage was routine, uneventful.  But the nearer they came to the Arctic Circle...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) Over these scenes: NARRATOR (cont'd) ...the more the tension increased, the more tiny irritations were magnified into bitter feuds...the more the crewmen pondered their possible rate at the end of the voyage...

dialogues.speaker: THE ANIMATED POLAR MAP
dialogues.text: With the course line still moving north.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: And now the entry reads:  MAY 20, 0900 HOURS CROSSED

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On the morning of May 20, the Tiger Shark crossed the Arctic Circle into the critical area...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This should consist of moving fields of bergs, avalanches polar bears, walrus, etc.

dialogues.speaker: TIGER SHARK
dialogues.text: Running at periscope depth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the viewer apparently pans over a field of floating icebergs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they come in.  Reef stops, glares as he sees Carl, sitting at one of the tables, making calculations on a pad, sipping coffee.  Carl looks up, catches Reef's eye.  Without a word, he finishes his coffee, picks up his material, and goes out.  Dave watches this tableau curiously.  When Carl is gone, Reef goes to the silex, pours a cup of coffee for himself and one for Dave. Dave joins him, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) You've asked why I stay a bachelor? There goes the best reason I know!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (puzzled) Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I might have a son like that!

dialogues.speaker: AT TABIE
dialogues.text: As Reef and Dave sit down.  Dave shakes his head, be- wildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get it.  What's with you two? Reef sips his coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess Skipper Neilsen re- tired before you enrolled at the Academy, didn't he?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sincerely) One of the finest men, and officers, alive.  A real hero - in the best sense of the word - in World War Two.  He taught us Engineering and Design. Fought like a demon to develop atom subs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) So all of a sudden his only son drops out of school, be- gins making noises like a pacifist.  A real egghead, do-gooder, and crackpot!  'Ban the atom tests!  Junk the nuclear subs!  Spend the mili- tary budgetfor peace!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (soberly) A lot of people think like that.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED 5-26-59 "ATOMIC SUBMARINE" 29-38
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly) But they're not Skipper Neilsen's son! (sadly) It broke his heart.  Then when some newspapers called Carl 'the honest, sincere son of a war-mongering father' - Captain Neilsen resigned from the Navy. (then) Oh, he still keeps his hand in - playing around with projects like the 'Lungfish' - but it broke him, all the same.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (broad-mindedly) Have you ever talked to Carl - tried to see his side?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sarcastically) 'His' side?  I've seen it, all right. A nice, bright yellow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave looks questioningly at Reef.  Reef drinks his coffee rapidly, then exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As he enters, climbs down the ladder to the torpedo room, starts forward.

dialogues.speaker: MED. FULL
dialogues.text: Chester and Powell are working on equipment for the little sub, which is stored below the escape hatch and will be used to launch it from the belly of the Tiger Shark. Reef enters, addresses the crewmen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Any of you men seen Dr. Neilsen? Chester turns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's here, Sir. Reef turns to the other men.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tuttle, would you mind leaving us alone for a minute? Chester Tuttle looks at Powell, who shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure, Mr. Holloway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) He and Powell go o.s. towards the men's dining room. Carl, sensing something, frowns, moves closer to Reef.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (contemptuously) Your 'out.' (as Carl looks puzzled) This came for you. (indicating the radiogram)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My father!  He's not - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dead? (he shakes his head) Matter of fact, he's much better. He's left the hospital. He hands the radiogram to Carl, who scans it eagerly, relaxes, vastly relieved.  Then he frowns, puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you mean:  I'm 'out?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your father can be in Nome, Alaska, tomorrow.  We have two choices: Ask them to send him out in a 'copter', and take you off, or the Shark can put back into Nome... Now Carl reacts angrily, hotly, for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You 'trade school boys' are all alike, aren't you?  Anybody who doesn't happen to think like a little gold-braided puppet is, ipso facto, a coward!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (angrily) You said it.  But I won't argue -

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wearing a uniform doesn't bestow an automatic monopoly on courage, Commander!  It just so happens I'm not a coward - physical or mental - and before I'd risk my father's life...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (interrupting) We're all risking our lives!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be.  But Dad stays where he is, and I'm staying here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (studying him) You're really a mixed-up oddball, aren't you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps.  But the idea of willingly going to school to spend my life at a Paleozoic pastime that should have disappeared with the thunder-lizards - I'm referring to War - that strikes me as the worst cowardice of all - being spiritually yellow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sneering) You mean nothing is worth fighting for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Peace - the dignity of man - the destiny of the human spirit! (hotly) Show me a man who says you win those by fighting wars, and I'll show you an idiot!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitterly) You may not win them.  But without men like your father, to 'degrade' himself by fighting to preserve them - or as much as we have of them - they'd have disappeared, long ago! Carl reacts to this.  The shot, for the first time, has struck home.  But then, just as he opens his mouth to say something, there is a TREMENDOUS, RATTLING CRASH...as if

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED - 2) the Tiger Shark had shattered a huge, infinite pane of glass under water.  The SCENE JUMPS.  Reef looks around, terribly alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the - ? Now there is the CLANGING of the GQ alarm, and over it, Wendover's voice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (filter) Mr. Holloway to the Con, please! On the double!

dialogues.speaker: REEF
dialogues.text: He runs to the end of the torpedo room, begins scrambling up the ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Present besides the seamen are the Skipper, Dave, Dr. Kent and Sir Ian.  The scene is bedlam - the Sonar is screaming weirdly, the SHATTERING CRASHES are repeated over and over, and the scene JUMPS WILDLY.  Dave points at the view screen, yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The instruments have all gone crazy!  And look at the view screen! The scientists peer over his shoulder, absorbed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (murmurs) Incredible!  Absolutely! Kent's jaw sets tensely.

dialogues.speaker: VIEW SCREEN AND INSTRUMENTS
dialogues.text: This is a wild extravaganza.  The radar pattern is jumbled, overlaid with a half-dozen wave-forms.  The dials and lights flicker and glow with utter insanity. And the view screen - it is a panoply of flashing, comet- like streaks, jagged streaks resembling lightning bolts, the while accompanied by staccato crashes, alarm bells, shattering bolts of thunder-like sound.

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING PAST THEM
dialogues.text: As Reef comes scrambling up into the Con.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shouting) What hit us???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (drily) The end of the world! Wendover spreads his hands helplessly.  Kent is still frowning at the view screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It doesn't seem possible, but - could it be an electrical storm center - ?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulous) Under water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High-intensity arcs will burn, submerged.  And millions of volts...discharged in random directions...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to Dave) Is there any way out of it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seems to be all around...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) What about down?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (surprised) I...don't know! Wendover turns to Reef:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're dead if we stay here, that's for sure. (bluntly) Take her down!  Maximum angle, maxi- mum depth!  Maybe even a little more!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aye, aye. He moves to the helm, begins AD LIBBING directions to the helmsman.  Wendover displays crossed fingers to Sir Ian, Kent and Dave.

dialogues.speaker: TIGER SHARK
dialogues.text: (This may also intercut earlier dialogue) It seems to be buffeted by an underwater storm.  The scene is lit by underwater lightning bolts, crashes like exploding skyrockets, the sub is tossed about like a chip.  Finally, when it seems that nothing can survive the electrical barrage, we see the nose tilt down steeply and the Shark glides deeper and deeper into the depths. CAMERA HOLDS as it goes below frame.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As it noses deeper and deeper into the depths, the bolts of lightning seem to follow it down, probing after it. But at last, the bolts are left behind, the turbulent waters are calm, the crashing noise subsides.  Then we see that the sub is almost on the bottom.  At last, it does touch and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 103 thru  (OMITTED) 107

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Present are the Skipper, Sir Ian, Dr. Kent, Carl and Reef.  They are just finishing the meal.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (almost as if be- ginning a lecture, he clears his throat) Sir Ian has evolved a theory.  At first, I wasn't about to buy it. (continued)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) KENT (cont'd) But, we have eliminated, one by one, every other logical explana- tion - The others turn eagerly to Sir Ian.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is rather fantastic - Sir Ian hesitates.  Then, from beside his chair, he picks up a large, rolled chart.  He unties the string binding it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here is a chart of the Arctic region.  On it I have plotted every instance of these strange phenomena - sinkings, electrical storms, our own experiences... He unrolls the chart on the table top.  Reef and Wendover exchange a perplexed look.  Then they get up, come around peer down over Sir Ian's shoulder at the chart.  Sir Ian, with a pencil, gestures on the chart.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: And as Sir Ian's pencil moves, we see a circle of 'X's' about the North Pole, equidistant from it, each marked with a date, and, in print too fine to be read, the circumstances.  As he points to one, in the Bering Straits...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here was where we encountered the electrical storm...The Sturgeon was lost just about this area. Others...here, here, and here...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sir Ian looks up from the chart, demands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you see it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pattern. (tapping the chart repeatedly) Each incident occurred almost precisely a thousand statute miles from the Pole.  A line through the points of occurrence makes almost a complete circle...

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE SHOT
dialogues.text: As Sir Ian's pencil follows his remarks, tracing this concentric circle about the polar region.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...about the North Pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Reef frowns, inquires bluntly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which adds up to what, Sir Ian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (significantly) I cannot accept the idea that these phenomena were either random, or natural. (a break) I believe they are motivated by... some sort of intelligence! The others react, Wendover and Reef exchange a look, then Wendover explodes angrily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean somebody has been - But Sir Ian interrupts him firmly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did not mean to imply, neces- sarily, a 'human' intelligence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (earnestly) Then - what on earth kind of in- telligence is it, Sir Ian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps not 'on earth' at all. Perhaps it comes from beyond the earth!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As they savor this alarming postulation.

dialogues.speaker: REEF AND CARL
dialogues.text: Carl looks at him uncertainly.  Reef asks grimly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can anything be done about it?

dialogues.speaker: KENT, WENDOVER AND SIR IAN
dialogues.text: Sir Ian looks thoughtfully at the chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've been thinking about that. (tapping the chart) These appearances of...whatever we're dealing with...make almost a complete ring around the Pole. But there is what may be a signifi- cant gap, or break, in the ring...

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: Which centers, now, on the region in question, which Sir Ian's dialogue describes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...right here...the Queen Victoria Sea area, near Franz Joseph Land...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Sir Ian looks up from the chart, but Captain Wendover continues to study it absorbedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...above Murmansk, and Finland.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking at Wendover) Suppose our theorizing is correct? Then this could be the next danger point!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if the Tiger Shark were to anticipate a bit?  Perhaps be lying there waiting - ? Wendover frowns, intrigued by the possibility.  Wen- dover beckons Reef over to the chart:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We'll chart a course straight across the pole - to bring us here - (he looks up into the tense faces) - the Queen Victoria Sea! Sir Ian and Kent exchange a look.  Reef looks at Carl, who frowns tensely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (OMITTED)

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP OF POLAR REGION
dialogues.text: And now the progress line of the Tiger Shark's voyage moves directly across the Pole.  As it reaches the Pole, a sign pops in: JUNE 1, 0730

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So - swiftly, implacably, the Tiger Shark moved across the Top of the World towards her rendezvous with...what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Dave's hands point out their position, course, and destination.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED 5-26-59 "ATOMIC SUBMARINE" 53-54
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been heading due south, 30 degrees longitude.  By my reckoning we're about ten angular seconds...

dialogues.speaker: DAVE REEF WENDOVER SIR IAN
dialogues.text: About Dave's navigator position.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (continuing) ...short of the Arctic meridian, and that should be...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking it up) ...the critical point - if we're on the right track.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Prepare to surface.  We'll run at flank speed.

dialogues.speaker: TIGER SHARK UNDERWATER
dialogues.text: It picks up speed, rises towards the surface.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There is a shout from the operator at the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Milburn - quick - look at this! They all move quickly to the TV screen.

dialogues.speaker: ICEBERG IN WATER
dialogues.text: We see a giant iceberg in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now we see what appears to be a strange glow of energy in the water beneath it.  The iceberg seems to creak and groan from internal pressures.

dialogues.speaker: COVER
dialogues.text: As the ball of energy seems to melt, rend and then literally explode the huge mass of ice.  The iceberg disintegrates and great masses of ice rush away from the explosion center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Reef yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skipper!  Those chunks of ice - coming right at us! The Skipper reacts, instantly yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dive!  Dive! (OMITTED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: During emergency dive procedure.  THE DIVE ALARM is sounding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, Sir Ian and Dr. Kent.

dialogues.speaker: TIGER SHARK
dialogues.text: As it institutes emergency dive, begins to move beneath the waves.  This INTERCUTS WITH:

dialogues.speaker: LARGE CHUNK OF ICE
dialogues.text: It rushes at express train speed directly toward Tiger Shark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Captain, Reef, and Dave and the crewmen work des- perately to get their sub into the safety of the depths. But now Dave, at the TV view screen, reacts in a frenzy to what he sees:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Captain!  Come here! But the Captain is too busy.

dialogues.speaker: UNDERWATER
dialogues.text: As the Tiger Shark has almost made it to safety, the great bulk of rushing ice lurches into frame, and just collides with the stern of the Tiger Shark.  There is a great CLANGING SHOCK and the Tiger Shark staggers like a stricken fish, then quickly rights herself. But the screws slow down, then stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Overlapping action above, as the scene LURCHES, and the men strive to maintain their balance.  Dave is still oblivious to everything except what he sees on the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps, to Reef) Determine extent of damage, immediately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grabbing an intercom phone) After torpedo room:  Report!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (over intercom) This is Griff, Captain.  Moderate leak in overhead plates.  Damage to main drive shaft housing. Forced to stop reactor engines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're dead in the water!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insistently) Skipper!  You've got to see this! You too, Sir Ian! Wendover and Sir Ian exchange a look, then move over behind Dave, look over his shoulder, react in astonish- ment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'll be - !

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (wryly) I'll be another!

dialogues.speaker: ON TELEVISION SCREEN
dialogues.text: On the screen is a great, oval-shaped, glowing ellipse- saucer-shaped.  It is perhaps three-hundred feet in diameter.  On top is a great, blazing turret of light, remotely resembling a lighthouse beacon - seemingly the 'eye' of the thing.  Beneath it are some sort of pro- tuberances, perhaps a landing or settling gear.  While they watch, the disc begins to recede from them.

dialogues.speaker: WENDOVER, SIR IAN, DAVE
dialogues.text: And then Reef joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it? And then he catches sight of the thing on the view- screen, frowns tensely.

dialogues.speaker: THE TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: And now the saucer grows smaller and smaller, until finally it is only a point of light.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps) Course and speed?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (adjusting dials) Speed...about twenty-two knots. Course...due north!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a thoughtful murmur) Directly towards the Pole! They look at him, trying to fathom his thoughts.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griff, in his undershirt, covered with grease and dirt, has obviously been laboring mightily at the damage.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) Powell and Carney are getting into full aqualung gear, including black rubber suits.  Griff looks them over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay - you two flounders look about set. (he hefts the air tanks on Powell's back and admonishes) And remember - this ain't no swimming pool - we need a damage report!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mutters) See what I mean about volunteering - But before he can finish the sentence, Griff pulls the face mask down over his nose and mouth.  Powell and Carney exit toward the stern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: With Sir Ian's hand, holding a pencil, completing the sketch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...a pure oval shape, with this cyclops-like eye, or turret, on top.  I'd estimate its diameter at 300 feet.  No discernible ori- fices...

dialogues.speaker: ABOUT TABLE
dialogues.text: This is a discussion group, or 'seminar' - and in the group are Sir Ian, Carl, Reef, Dave and Wendover.  Sir Ian leans back, holding the pencil, while his sketch is passed around from one to the next.  With a faintly amused expression, Sir Ian murmurs thoughtfully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'The Eye of Cyclops..!'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (looking up from the drawing) What did you say, Sir Ian?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just musing about our 'one-eyed adversary' and the legend of Homer. (to the group) 'Cyclopes' were the Sons of Heaven, who forged the thunder- bolts thrown by Zeus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) Our 'Cyclops' throws quite a thunderbolt, itself! Now Dr. Kent appears in the doorway, carrying a well- filled briefcase, from which he has extracted a manila folder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with satis- faction) I knew there was something familiar - He puts down the briefcase, takes an 8 x 10 photograph from the manila folder, then lays the folder aside. He tosses the photograph on the table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take a look. They peer at it curiously, then someone lays Sir Ian's sketch alongside it.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSEUP
dialogues.text: And we see that the object in the photo - a 'flying saucer' - closely resembles the sketch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The picture was taken by an amateur astronomer, over New Mexico.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As all examine the photos, astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've had it since I served on the Air Force Evaluation Board, for UFO reports. As Sir Ian looks up inquiringly, Carl explains:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Unidentified Flying Objects.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (incredulously) Then...this is a 'flying saucer?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was the popular designation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (curiously) But...weren't all the sightings in the sky - not under water? Sir Ian picks up the photo, studies it as he reflects:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This would explain why there were never any reports of land- ings.  It's possible that who- ever - or whatever - inhabits the craft is not a land creature, but a form of marine life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a wry smile) That would make our 'little green men' actually 'little grean fish'???

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shakes his head, marvelling) Undersea flying saucers!

dialogues.speaker: SHOOTING PAST GROUP
dialogues.text: as Griff appears in it, dishevelled as before, but with a look of satisfaction.  He makes a gesture of knocking, says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Skipper---

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, Griff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All internal repairs completed, and Frogmen report exterior damage minor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with eager satisfaction) Then we can get under way? As Griff nods, all look toward Wendover for orders.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (snaps at Dave) You plotted the course of Cyclops? (as Dave nods) Then that's our course!  Wherever he goes, we go.....until we get him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (an absent murmur) Or, perhaps, until he gets us? A look passes among them; that possibility is by no means remote.

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP OF POLAR AREA
dialogues.text: with the Tiger Shark course moving back and forth, up and around, the Pole.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, the Tiger Shark began relentlessly stalking her space-enemy.  Up to the Pole, back to the Arctic Circle... again, and again...a week... a fortnight, a month....

dialogues.speaker: THE TIGER SHARK
dialogues.text: moving implacably through undersea caverns, between hidden mountains, under glaciers, etc. (Omit semi-montage about Tiger Shark).

dialogues.speaker: ANIMATED MAP OF POLAR AREA
dialogues.text: And now the lines for the voyage make up almost a star-design about the Pole, up and back, to all quarters. Over these scenes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never a glimpse of their enemy, but there were reports...new disasters, new ships and lives lost.  Invariably, the Tiger Shark made for the scene, only to arrive after Cyclops had left. For all its desperatian, the pursuit seemed fruitless.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then, on July 3, Dr. Kent and Sir Ian held an urgent discussion with Reef and the Skipper...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: which appears like a great star - away from the Pole, back to it - away - back, as in the animated chart earlier.  Now Kent's voice, desperately urgent, comes

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) over, as his hand taps a pencil repeatedly directly on the Pole. KENT (o.s.) Why does Cyclops invariably return to the Pole between attacks - never two in succession.  Always away... and back....away....and back....

dialogues.speaker: KENT, REEF, WENDOVER AND SIR IAN
dialogues.text: about the chart.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've asked ourselves that - over and over - a thousand times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritably) But answers are what we need - not more questions!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (significantly) We think maybe, now, we have them! Reef and Wendover react.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We took for granted his source of energy was nuclear.  But suppose it isn't at all - what if it's magnetic?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We harness energy on a small scale by cutting magnetic lines of force.  Maybe Cyclops does it on a super scale....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (significantly again) The North Pole is the positive end of the biggest magnet of all - the Earth itself!

dialogues.speaker: REEF AND WENDOVER
dialogues.text: Wendover considers this gravely as Reef responds:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What you're getting at:  You think our saucer-friend has to return to the Pole, regularly to....recharge his batteries?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That may be over-simplifying, but--- He doesn't finish the sentence, obviously implying that Reef's conclusion agrees with their own.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now:  Our present tactics are hopeless.  But suppose we could place ourselves between Cyclops and the Pole....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Sir Ian picks up Kent's thought:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....in such a way as to prevent his returning to it and, as you put it.... (a nod toward Reef) ...'recharging his batteries'?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If we were lucky enough to catch him with his power depleted....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (triumphantly) ....we could polish him off with an atomic fish! (claps Reef on the shoulder) That's it, Reef!  We'll wait until the next report of trouble.  Then we'll lay on the bottom, right in his path, and bushwack him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (frowns, puzzled) 'Bushwack?'

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (a faint smile) American tactical expression. And as Reef and Wendover exchange a look, we...

dialogues.speaker: TIGER SHARK
dialogues.text: cruising at slow speed under the ice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So - a chance of tactics.  Now the Tiger Shark cruised almost over the North Pole, waiting for the radio report that would put the plan into effect... On July 13, at 1600 hours, it came!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: drinking coffee.  Behind him, now, we see Dave burst in excitedly from passage way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got it, Reef! Reef springs to his feet excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cyclops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like it!  Distress call, from a small freighter, between Ellesmere Island and Greenland. One mayday, then...nothing. As Reef moves toward the door, he demands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's the Skipper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Already in the Con! The two men exit.  Now CAMERA ROLLS IN FOR CLOSEUP OF CARL, who, standing in the door, has overheard the conversation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dave is working over his navigation chart. The tension in the Con is electric.  Dave takes a compass, swings a pair of arcs on the chart, looks up to announce:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're here! Wendover and the others cluster around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure? Dave indicates on the chart.

dialogues.speaker: THE POLAR CHART
dialogues.text: with a distinct line drawn from the reported sinking to the Pole and another line...the course of the Tiger Shark, just now intercepting it. DAVE (o.s.) Here's where Cyclops knocked off the freighter.  Here's the way he has to head for home... the Pole.  And... (indicates the intersection) Here we are...right in his path!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (decisively) All right, then we're for it, right here. Sonar and TV, scan the bottom, find a nice spot for us to lie and wait for him -- maybe a cave, or a valley.

dialogues.speaker: REVISED 5-26-59 "ATOMIC SUBMARINE" 68-69-70
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) WENDOVER (cont'd) (to Reef) Soon as we're on the bottom, go through the boat, batten down whatever makes a noise, and turn off anything that hums or buzzes.  I want absolute silence! They AD LIB further commands and movement about the con as we...

dialogues.speaker: THE TIGER SHARK
dialogues.text: as she eases her way deep under the ice, sonar PINGS probing the way.  At last, she eases down onto the bottom in a hallow, or undersea cave.  The propellers are still, the ship lies silent, motionless, seemingly dead.

dialogues.speaker: TIGER SHARK ON BOTTOM
dialogues.text: There is no sign of life whatever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hour upon hour, the Tiger Shark lay in its deep-six ambush... The Arctic depths were as still and silent as an uninhabited world.  Then, at 0600 hours....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see Kent and Sir Ian, dozing in their chairs.  Wendove himself is nodding.  Now CAMERA MOVES to Dave, who yawns prodigiously, reaches for his coffeecup, finds to his dis gust that it is empty.  Then, almost absent-mindedly, he glances teward the gauges and view-plates.  He reacts.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE UP
dialogues.text: which is labeled:  RADIATION LEVEL.  The needle-flickers, makes a slight jump, then rises to a positive reading.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE
dialogues.text: He reacts, all attention now.  He turns dials to get a bearing on the source of radiation.  Then he swings aroun in his chair to the television monitor, moves the dials t focus the TV camera in the direction of the radiation.

dialogues.speaker: OPTICAL SHOT OF TV SCREEN
dialogues.text: And very faintly, in the extreme distance, we see a tiny speck of light growing slowly larger.

dialogues.speaker: PAST DAVE
dialogues.text: as Dave calls in a sharp whisper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Skipper!  Dr. Kent! Instantly, the men come alert, move over behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED) In answer, Dave points to the view screen.  Both men re- act, exchange a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's him!  Has to be!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking dials) Range, about twenty-two miles. Speed....I give it fourteen knots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking in- struments) His radiation level is very low! (to Wendover) That would confirm our theory - about having to return to the Pole!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (grimly) It better be correct! (to Dave) Get me a setup on the TDC - range, about seven miles!

dialogues.speaker: THE CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: As Wendover moves to the intercom, Dave goes to work on the torpedo data computer.  Sir Ian and Kent study the instruments.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into phone) Skipper to Exec:  Arm atomic warheads!  Load 1 and 2... Report to Con pronto! Part of the above overlaps following:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the VOICE comes over the intercom, Griff reacts, looks at Reef:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sounds like we mean business! Reef doesn't deign to answer.  He gestures to Griff:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griff, you arm No. 2.  I'll handle No. 1. Griff nods, moves over to one of the panel boards and starts manipulating it.  Meantime, Reef is doing the same thing on another panel.

dialogues.speaker: COVER
dialogues.text: thru

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As the arming is finished, and Reef moves from dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Load One and Two.  Then open outer doors! (grimly) And stand by for action! Reef hurries to the far end of the torpedo room, and be- gins climbing the ladder.  He glances back to see that Griff and another man are manipulating dials to open the inner tube doors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as we see the outer doors slowly lift, disclosing the torpedo warheads inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Dave sings out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Range:  Now fifteen miles! Now Reef climbs up into the con, demands:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're sure it's Cyclops?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (gesturing toward TV screen) Take a look. Reef comes over, stares, fascinated, down over Dave's shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: OPTICAL SHOT
dialogues.text: And now, in the TV screen, we can just make out the faint outlines of the approaching saucer - the oval shape, the glowing turret-eye.  O.s., Dave now sings out: DAVE (o.s.) Range...now 14.5 miles.

dialogues.speaker: DAVE AND REEF
dialogues.text: as they look down anxiously at the screen.  Now there is a VOICE over the intercom: GRIFF (o.s.) (filter) Griff to Skipper.  Tubes One and Two loaded.  Outer doors open.  Ready to fire. WENDOVER (o.s.) (obviously into phone) Stand by!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (OMITTED)

dialogues.speaker: THE CYCLOPS
dialogues.text: Through an undersea valley, the Cyclops moves silently, its glowing eye probing ahead for possible danger.

dialogues.speaker: THE TIGER SHARK
dialogues.text: still lying silently, in wait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It is approaching very near, now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ENDING on Dave and Reef.  Now Dave sings out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Range....ten miles!!

dialogues.speaker: OVER TIGER SHARK
dialogues.text: This is the first tie-in shot, showing the relative posi- tions of the two craft.  The Cyclops should still be a considerable distance away - merely a glowing spot in the water.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griff stands near the firing buttons for tubes One and Two - clearly labeled.  The tension is building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And on it, we see that Dave has adjusted cross-hairs for the Target Zero.  The saucer moves across the view screen, toward the Target Zero. DAVE (o.s.) Range...eight miles.... Seven and three-quarters.....

dialogues.speaker: CYCLOPS
dialogues.text: It looms huge and awesome IN CAMERA, now, sweeps by and above CAMERA and o.s.  There is an awful RUSHING SOUND as it sweeps overhead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Dave sings out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Zero minus ten....nine....

dialogues.speaker: OPTICAL SHOT
dialogues.text: The Cyclops approaches closer and closer to the 'x.' DAVE (o.s.) ....eight...seven.....six.... five....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ....four....three....two....

dialogues.speaker: OPTICAL SHOT
dialogues.text: And now the Cyclops moves directly into the cross of the 'x.' DAVE (o.s.) ....one....Target.....

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excitedly) Zero!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (barks into intercom) Fire Number One!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Griff moves swiftly, presses the firing lever, then barks into intercom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number One fired!

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON TORPEDO TUBE
dialogues.text: as the first torpedo bursts out and speeds away toward target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (into intercom) Fire Number Two!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Griff fires Number Two, then reports:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number Two fired!

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON TORPEDO TUBE
dialogues.text: as the second torpedo shoots from its tube after the first.

dialogues.speaker: TYING TIGER SHARK AND CYCLOPS
dialogues.text: And now we see the two torpedos, executing a great curving arc, 'homing' on their target.  They are still a considerable distance from it.

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON TWO TORPEDOS
dialogues.text: as they WHOOSH BY CAMERA, speeding toward their target.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wendover checks his watch, demands of Reef:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (CONTINUED)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the running time?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking TDC) Thirty-four seconds! All wait, tense, breathless, expectant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Carl, the crew, Griff and others, all silently counting the seconds.

dialogues.speaker: THE SAUCER
dialogues.text: Now the luminous eye seems to turn to observe the ap- proaching menace.  There is a THROBBING BUZZ as of an energy discharge, and then the first torpedo comes in scene, seems to swerve to avoid the Cyclops, goes plunging on past it and o.s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: as Dave, agony and disappointment in his tone, calls:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Number One...Missed! There is an AD LIB response of shock.  Then Wendover complains to Reef:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How could it?  We were dead on target, with a homing torpedo!

dialogues.speaker: THE SAUCER
dialogues.text: Now, from some vent within the vehicle, a cloud of radi- ant, luminescent 'jelly' seems to stream out, enveloping it in a protective cloud.  Just as the cloud is well- formed about the saucer, obscuring its outlines...

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON SECOND TORPEDO
dialogues.text: It plunges through scene and off towards the saucer.

dialogues.speaker: AT SAUCER
dialogues.text: as the second torpedo burrows into the protective cloud, more and more slowly, probing vainly toward the still- visible 'eye.'  Then...

dialogues.speaker: CLOSE ON TORPEDO
dialogues.text: as it buries itself in the mass of luminescent jelly. The propellers thrash madly, ineffectually.  Then, gradually, they slow down, and the torpedo is completely surrounded by the mysterious mass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AND OVERLAPPING ACTION ABOVE, we see the torpedo slow down and stop, buried in the mass surrounding the saucer. DAVE (o.s.) Skipper - look at this!

dialogues.speaker: LOW ANGLE
dialogues.text: as Reef, Wendover, Kent and Sir Ian cluster tightly about Dave.  Carl enters from the hatch, joins them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) A mass of jelly-like stuff came out of the thing, and caught our torpedo!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exclaims) What??? Kent frowns, points.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It must function like a de-Gaussing field. (dubiously) We'll never get a torpedo through that! Now Wendover's jaw sets grimly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe not a torpedo... They look at him as he moves o.s. to the intercom.

dialogues.speaker: WENDOVER
dialogues.text: as he barks into the intercom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the Captain:  Blow bow tanks.  Reactor Room, stand by: Soon as we're off the bottom, I want all ahead, flank speed, pronto!

dialogues.speaker: THE CONTROL ROOM
dialogues.text: as Dave asks alertly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What course, Skipper?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (with grim purpose) Right at our one-eyed friend! There are AD LIB surprised exclamations from all.  Reef is incredulous:
